awd_abstract_narration:
The main objective of this project is to further scholarly understanding about the phenomenon of territory management among groups in organizations. Territory management in organizations is a natural behavior stemming from evolutionary pressures to reinforce or expand one's own group's territory within an environment, but can have both beneficial and harmful outcomes in modern day organizations. While beneficial outcomes of territory management in organizations can include decision efficacy, team cohesion, and clear expectations about work, harmful outcomes include lost market share, missed opportunities, gridlock, and a cycle of relational deterioration among groups. Little is currently understood about what territory management looks like in organizations, what the conditions are that lead to harmful versus beneficial consequences, and how territory management might be reinforced in organizations.  The proposed research uses a mixed method approach to study this phenomenon in organizations. Two studies will be conducted. The first involves a qualitative study into the behaviors and forms through which territory management manifests in organizations, and possible conditions that lead to harmful versus beneficial effects. The second study will involve a dynamic computation modeling study to test factors that may reinforce cycles of territory management in organizations. Findings will be used to help managers identify if a cycle of territory management among their groups is occurring and possible leverage points they may have to break the loop of territory management among their groups if necessary. Further, the proposed research will help future researchers more advantageously target their resources in conducting research on cross-group conflict over organizational territories. 

Territory management in organizations is a natural behavior stemming from evolutionary pressures to reinforce or expand one's own group's territory within an environment, but can have both beneficial and harmful outcomes in modern day organizations. The current project seeks to better understand this phenomenon in organizations using a mixed method approach by (1) collecting empirical data to articulate the behaviors and forms in which territory management between groups manifest, and to begin linking these behaviors and forms to antecedents and consequences; (2) formally modeling key theoretical features relevant to territory management among groups in organizations through a computational model informed by literature and data from the empirical study; and (3) begin testing propositions and emergent predictions within the extended theoretical space that only computational modeling allows (e.g., enabling the exploration of emergent outcomes arising from individual groups interacting and reacting to one another and their environment over time). This project will help develop and refine a conceptual model of territory management and offer a new lens through which to understand cross-group interactions.  A territory management lens has the potential to synthesize aspects of intergroup conflict, such as group identity, finite resources, uncertainty and change, legitimacy, and control and autonomy, into a more parsimonious model.  The proposed computational modeling approach will help to test which variables are fundamental in a system view of territory management, while the proposed empirical study may help begin to untangle what types of territory management behaviors may be beneficial or harmful to groups (and their organizations).

por.por_cntn:
INTELLECTUAL MERIT

This project, which explores the phenomenon of territory management between groups, helped to refine our conceptual model of cross-group territory management and offers a new lens through which to understand cross-group interactions.  First, the computational model helped to test theoretical conditions under which an organizational system may experience greater or fewer territory management behaviors between groups, when (if at all) territory ownership may reach equilibrium, and the degree of "repeat conflict" groups may experience (e.g., all else being equal, greater need for group security increases territory management behaviors between groups; different organizational forms affect the amount of cross-group territory behaviors). Second, the empirical study is an initial step to identify the types of cross-group territory management behaviors that are common in organizations by exploring territory management behaviors and their consequences (e.g., this study confirmed preliminary findings that groups will engage in specific overt and covert strategic behaviors to position themselves favorably for a desired or contested territory).

This work has implications for theorists and researchers considering cross-group conflict. It suggests that we need to not only think about internal group characteristics and ingroup/outgroup biases, but to also consider external conditions related to territories inside the organization – for example, what other territory options a group feels are open to it, how closely another group’s territory(ies) is connected to the target group’s territory(ies), the degree to which the organizational environment fosters easily threatened or highly secure groups (independent of territories), and the degree to which the organizational environment values a range of territories. 

 

BROADER IMPACTS

Findings from this project will help researchers more advantageously target their resources in conducting research on cross-group conflict over organizational territories.  Group-based empirical research is notoriously expensive to conduct, and the work from this study provides suggestions on specific variables that resource-constrained researchers may wish to target their time and resources toward if they are investigating this phenomenon. For example, the virtual experiment/computational model suggests that organizational structure, sense of security, and ratio of “territory options : groups” are fundamental factors influencing the phenomenon. 

The project also offered benefits through the activities directly related to conducting the research. It helped train a graduate student in organizational research and allow the individual to learn a new scientific method (computational modeling).

Additionally, the project provides insight to managers about signals and possible levers they can employ to better assess and facilitate their organizations' cross-group relations. For example, results from the empirical study, by providing a grounded framework of manifest behaviors that arise when groups engage in territory management, may help managers detect when a cycle of territory management among their groups is likely occurring. Detection and awareness, in turn, provides managers with the opportunity to address the cycle.  Results from the computational model may inform leaders on leverage points they have to manage levels of territory behaviors more generally in their organizations. For example, leaders' reinforcement to groups that a variety of territories have high value to the organization – whether the territory content is, say, traditionally considered a “cost center” versus a revenue generator – is likely to make a difference in how driven groups may be to acquire or contest other groups’ territories.
